vectorData.altText: USING a scalpel, make a careful horizontal cut

nucleus, the globus pallidus.  Removal of a portion of the lentiform in this manner will reveal the continuation of the corona radiata as the internal capsule. 
The internal capsule consists of projection fibres running medial to the lentiform nucleus. Anteriorly, it lies between the lentiform and the head of the caudate nucleus, forming the anterior limb of the internal capsule. Posteriorly, the internal capsule lies between the lentiform and the thalamus forming the posterior limb of the internal capsule.  The inflection point between the anterior and posterior limbs of the internal capsule is the genu. Identify these structures in the accompanying figure. To better understand the corpus striatum in this horizontal section, click here:
through the lentiform and remove its superior half. Look, in the cut surface, the more fibrous, and therefore paler, portion of the lentiform
L. cerebral hemisphere, horizontal section. From Serial Dissections of the Human Brain, by Carlton G. Smith, M.D., Ph.D., © 1981 by Gage.
20.1   The Corpus Striatum and Internal Capsule

A horizontal section through the cerebral hemisphere and corpus striatum shows:
i) the anterior limb of the internal capsule passing between the head of the caudate nucleus and the lentiform nucleus, 
ii) the posterior limb of the internal capsule passing between the and thalamus and the lentiform nucleus,
iii) the genu of the internal capsule in between.
